author: __kasey__
content:
I have a question about https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/3506

I just want to confirm - the `Container` spec doesn't specify an outer `{data: ... }` object. Are we dropping the outer data envelope with this change (I've always been a bit mystified why we have it)? If not, where is the extra wrapper specified?

author: nflaig
content:
The data envelope is only required on the API level to separate actual data from the metadata. This allows to easily translate a json response to a ssz response as as the content of `data` field would be ssz serialized and other top-level properties (metadata) are set as http headers.

There is a comment in the spec regarding data field https://github.com/ethereum/beacon-APIs/blob/master/beacon-node-oapi.yaml#L14-L16
> All JSON responses return the requested data under a `data` key in the top
>  level of their response.  Additional metadata may or may not be present in other keys at the top level of the response, dependent
>  on the endpoint.

author: __kasey__
content: Thanks. Although tbqh I don't understand why we put metadata in the payload and not in headers? This would make the response completely consistent with the ssz variant. Seems like tech debt we may not want to carry forward indefinitely.

author: jgm
content: At the time the API was defined it was JSON-only, and having metadata in the response allows the response to be self-sufficient .

author: __kasey__
content: Gotcha, sounds like something we could clean up at some point going forward.

author: .paulharris
content: to be honest most of the metadata now seems to end up in headers anyway

author: nflaig
content: Having the metdata as part of the json body is convient for users if you wanna quickly do a curl, not need to inspect the headers. There are also bunch of apis that return metadata, e.g. `dependent_root` that do not (yet) have a header defined in the spec. Another issue might be `eventstream` API as you can't send the metadata as part of headers since it is possible to subscribe to multiple topics.
